article.title: Implications of $z ∼6$ Quasar Proximity Zones for the Epoch of Reionization and Quasar Lifetimes

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the blue curve in Figure 1 represent?
choices: The noise vector of the spectrum
The continuum model fitted to the whole spectral region (1020 ˚A ≤ λrest ≤ 1600 ˚A)
The continuum model fitted only to the red side of the spectrum (1215.67 ˚A≤ λrest ≤ 1600 ˚A)

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the vertical black dashed lines in Figure 2 represent?
choices: Locations of associated metal absorption lines
The extent of the Gunn-Peterson trough
The extent of the quasar proximity zone

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the primary conclusion drawn from comparing the simulated (gray dashed line) and observed (red dashed line) relations between proximity zone size and quasar magnitude in Figure 5?
choices: The observed luminosity scaling is significantly steeper than predicted by simulations.
The observed luminosity scaling is significantly shallower than predicted by simulations.
The observed and simulated luminosity scalings are in reasonable agreement.
There is no discernible correlation between proximity zone size and quasar magnitude in the observed data.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 6 primarily demonstrate about the redshift evolution of luminosity-corrected proximity zone sizes?
choices: Observed proximity zone sizes exhibit a steep decrease with redshift, consistent with previous analyses.
Observed proximity zone sizes exhibit a shallow redshift evolution, inconsistent with previous analyses.
Observed proximity zone sizes show no significant redshift evolution.
Proximity zone sizes are too sensitive to quasar luminosity to discern a clear redshift trend.
